Trial_Design.evidence: Three groups were studied: a nonobese group with severe OSAS, an obese group with severe OSAS, and a control group.

Participants.evidence: Children 5–12 years of age who were presenting for surgery

Intervention.evidence: Children 5–12 years of age who were presenting for surgery were administered a morphine dose of 0.05 mg/kg.

Objective.evidence: We hypothesized that obesity along with sleep apnea and leptin independently enhance morphine pharmacokinetics.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Blood was collected at baseline and at subsequent preset times for pharmacokinetic analysis of morphine and its metabolites.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Thirty-four patients consisting of controls (n = 16), nonobese/OSAS (n = 8), and obese/OSAS (n = 10) underwent analysis.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Thirty-four patients consisting of controls (n = 16), nonobese/OSAS (n = 8), and obese/OSAS (n = 10) underwent analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The obese/OSAS group had a higher dose-adjusted mean maximum morphine concentration (C MAX ) over 540 minutes compared to the controls ( P < .001) and those with only OSAS ( P = .014).
